page.title: 20Union Chain Bridge
page.content: a Until 1883 tolls were charged for crossing the Union Chain Bridge.The toll-keepers house built at the base of the English Tower was demolished in 1955,but the toll house of the Berwick -shire Turnpike Trust still stands near the Scottish end of the bridge. Under Scottish law toll-houses could sell liquor and marriages could take place there.It aquired unwelcome notor -iety, but whisky drinking ceased in 1854 and marriages in 1857. The cost of builing the bridge in 1880 was estimated at Â£7700 which included a gratuity to Capt. Brown. In 1973 a 10 year repair programme was commenced and the bridge will now remain the fine looking structure built so long ago and will only require minimal main -tenance for the next 50 years. It is now maintained by The Tweed Bridge Trust financed by local authorities.
